defenses.defense: Continued litigation posed substantial risk of no recovery or a smaller recovery for shareholders.
defenses.legal_basis: Risk-benefit analysis under Rule 23(e) and securities class action precedent emphasizing uncertainty of trial outcomes and collection.

defenses.defense: Absence of objections from class members supports approval of the settlement and fee request.
defenses.legal_basis: Class action settlement approval standards considering reaction of the class as a factor in determining fairness and adequacy.

case_name: TSUPKO v. KINETIC ADVANTAGE LLC
ai_relevance: Party’s filings appeared to rely on AI, causing fake citations.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual car dealer/borrower in credit dispute
parties.defendant_description: Business entity providing line of credit financing

claims.claim: Dispute over obligations and rights under a line of credit for a car dealership, including alleged wrongful conduct by Kinetic Advantage related to that credit facility.
claims.legal_basis: State contract and related commercial law claims (mirroring those in parallel Hamilton County state case).
claims.outcome: No merits ruling; federal court stayed all proceedings under Colorado River abstention pending resolution of the parallel state court action.

defenses.defense: Federal court should abstain from exercising jurisdiction because a parallel state court case between the same parties involves the same issues and can fully resolve the dispute.
defenses.legal_basis: Colorado River abstention doctrine and principles of wise judicial administration.

case_name: Lamont v. Conner et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves alleged misappropriation of AI software product designs.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual alleging trade secret misappropriation
parties.defendant_name: Kevin J. Conner, Google Ventures, others
parties.defendant_description: Individual defendants and corporate investor entity

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets relating to software product designs and innovative AI solutions
claims.legal_basis: Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA), 18 U.S.C. § 1836 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as to the Conner Defendants and Catherine Stephanie Straggas for lack of personal jurisdiction; dismissed as to Google Ventures for insufficiently pleaded allegations, but dismissal without prejudice and with leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Court lacks personal jurisdiction over the Conner Defendants and Catherine Stephanie Straggas
defenses.legal_basis: Federal due process limits on personal jurisdiction; insufficient minimum contacts with the forum state.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to state a plausible claim for trade secret misappropriation against Google Ventures
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) requiring sufficient factual allegations to state a claim under the DTSA.

case_id: 2022-03-23_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Clearview AI’s facial recognition system built from scraped images.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individuals and putative class alleging privacy and constitutional violations
parties.defendant_description: AI company and municipal entities using facial recognition database

claims.claim: Improper creation and use of facial recognition database from scraped online images without consent, violating privacy rights under the California Constitution.
claims.legal_basis: California Constitution, right to privacy; state constitutional privacy jurisprudence.
claims.outcome: Court found a reasonable possibility plaintiffs could succeed against municipal defendants; claims kept intact and case remanded to state court.

claims.claim: Violation of free speech rights under the California Constitution by collecting, storing, and using plaintiffs’ images in Clearview’s facial recognition database without consent.
claims.legal_basis: California Constitution, free speech protections as applied to misuse of personal images and biometric data.
claims.outcome: Court held claims against nondiverse municipal defendants were at least plausibly viable; refused to sever them and remanded entire action to state court.

claims.claim: Liability of municipal defendants for using Clearview’s facial recognition database that was allegedly created and maintained in violation of plaintiffs’ constitutional privacy and free speech rights.
claims.legal_basis: California constitutional privacy and free speech provisions; state-law theories attaching liability to government entities using unlawfully obtained data.
claims.outcome: Court ruled municipal defendants were not fraudulently joined, allowed claims to proceed against them in state court, and granted motion to remand under 28 U.S.C. § 1447(e).

defenses.defense: Municipal defendants were fraudulently joined solely to defeat federal diversity jurisdiction and should be disregarded for jurisdictional purposes.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal fraudulent joinder doctrine; 28 U.S.C. §§ 1332, 1441, 1447(e).

defenses.defense: Claims against municipal defendants are not viable and should be severed, allowing the case against Clearview AI to remain in federal court.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal procedural and removal statutes, including 28 U.S.C. § 1447(e), and case law on severance and remand.

case_name: Jones v. Google LLC, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged Google misrepresented itself as an artificial intelligence research company, but AI was only tangential to the consumer-protection claim.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer and Google Plus user
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation providing online services

claims.claim: Violation of the Kansas Consumer Protection Act based on loss of access to Google Plus web address and various Google services after shutdown of Google Plus and alleged misrepresentations by Google, including about its status as an artificial intelligence research company.
claims.legal_basis: Kansas Consumer Protection Act (KCPA) – deceptive or unconscionable acts in a consumer transaction.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a claim; allegations lacked specificity as to time, place, and content of any false representations and did not adequately define a qualifying consumer transaction.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim under the KCPA because it does not plead with requisite specificity any deceptive or unconscionable act, including the time, place, or content of alleged misrepresentations, nor does it identify a specific consumer transaction.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted (Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6)); pleading standards under Twombly/Iqbal and KCPA requirements for particularity.

case_name: Naughton v. Amazon.com, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Alleged use of facial recognition and biometric scanning systems for employee wellness checks.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual employee and class representative
parties.defendant_description: Corporate employer and related entities

claims.claim: Amazon collected employees’ biometric identifiers and information, including facial geometry, during wellness checks without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b) – collection without written notice and release.
claims.outcome: Court held allegations plausibly state a BIPA §15(b) claim and denied Amazon’s motion to dismiss as to this theory.

claims.claim: Amazon possessed and stored employees’ biometric data without a publicly available retention schedule or guidelines for permanent destruction.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(a) – lack of retention schedule and destruction policy.
claims.outcome: Court held allegations plausibly state a BIPA §15(a) claim and denied Amazon’s motion to dismiss as to this theory.

claims.claim: Amazon disclosed or otherwise disseminated employees’ biometric data to third parties without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(d) – disclosure or dissemination without consent.
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiff’s allegations sufficient at the pleading stage and denied Amazon’s motion to dismiss the BIPA §15(d) claim.

claims.claim: Amazon profited from or derived value from employees’ biometric data collected through facial scans.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(c) – prohibition on selling or profiting from biometric data.
claims.outcome: To the extent alleged, the court found the complaint stated a plausible claim and declined to dismiss at the motion to dismiss stage.

claims.claim: Class action claim on behalf of similarly situated Amazon employees subjected to biometric collection during wellness checks.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23; underlying BIPA violations (740 ILCS 14/15(a), (b), (c), (d)).
claims.outcome: Case allowed to proceed past motion to dismiss; class certification not yet decided.

defenses.defense: The complaint fails to state a claim because the alleged wellness-check facial scans do not constitute “biometric identifiers” or “biometric information” under BIPA.
defenses.legal_basis: Argument based on statutory definitions in 740 ILCS 14/10 and pleading standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Amazon did not collect, possess, or disclose biometric data in a manner covered by BIPA, or any such use was too attenuated or incidental to fall within the statute.
defenses.legal_basis: Interpretation of scope and reach of BIPA, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq., and application of Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Even if data was collected, plaintiff did not adequately allege dissemination or profit from biometric data to support separate BIPA subsections.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading sufficiency under Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a) and 12(b)(6) as to BIPA §§15(c) and 15(d).

defenses.defense: Any alleged violations are not actionable because plaintiff suffered no concrete injury beyond statutory violations.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III standing requirements under the U.S. Constitution and related federal case law on intangible harms.

case_id: 2022-07-25_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Defendant allegedly used AI facial recognition on scraped images, triggering BIPA claims.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of individuals alleging biometric privacy violations
parties.defendant_description: Facial recognition company and associated individual defendants

claims.claim: Unlawful collection of biometric identifiers and information without informed written consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Court previously allowed BIPA claims to proceed; in this order, it denies defendants’ reconsideration arguments challenging standing and jurisdiction, so the BIPA 15(b) claim remains pending.

claims.claim: Unlawful capture and use of facial geometry from online images via AI algorithms
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), generally including 740 ILCS 14/15(a), 15(b), and/or 15(c)-(d) as pled in the class action
claims.outcome: Court does not dismiss these BIPA-based theories; by denying reconsideration, it leaves intact its prior rulings allowing plaintiffs’ BIPA claims to go forward.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA by Clearview’s provision of its facial recognition database and services to government entities
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), including alleged inapplicability of the government-contractor exemption
claims.outcome: Court rejects defendants’ attempt on reconsideration to rely on the BIPA government-contractor exemption; any such defense-based challenge to the BIPA claim is deemed waived at this stage, so the claim remains.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over certain defendants
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction; Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(2)

defenses.defense: Lack of Article III standing for plaintiffs’ BIPA claims
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III case-or-controversy requirement; standing doctrine

defenses.defense: Government-contractor exemption under BIPA bars liability for work done for government clients
defenses.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) statutory exemption for government contractors

defenses.defense: Arguments raised for the first time on reconsideration should alter prior rulings
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b) / inherent authority to reconsider interlocutory orders (procedural reconsideration standard)

case_name: Gutierrez v. Wemagine.AI LLP
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI-powered photo-editing app collecting biometric facial data.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual Illinois user bringing class action
parties.defendant_description: Canadian company operating Voila AI Artist app

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting and storing facial geometry and biometric identifiers via the Voila AI Artist app without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over Wemagine.AI LLP; court did not reach the merits of the BIPA claim.

claims.claim: Class action claim on behalf of similarly situated Illinois users whose biometric data was allegedly collected and stored without proper consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 (class action mechanism).
claims.outcome: Effectively dismissed without prejudice when the entire action was dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction because Wemagine.AI, a Canadian company, did not purposefully direct activities or targeted marketing at Illinois; any contacts with Illinois arose solely from users’ unilateral decision to download and use the app.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction; minimum contacts and purposeful availment standards under cases such as International Shoe and its progeny.

case_id: 2022-05-26_USCOURTS-flsd-1_21-cv-23472_Birmingham et al v. Rofx.net et al.pdf
case_name: Birmingham et al. v. RoFx.net et al.
ai_relevance: Platform marketed as AI-powered forex trading system; alleged fraudulent AI representations induced investments.

parties.plaintiff_description: Group of investors alleging forex fraud scheme
parties.defendant_description: Online forex platform and UK payment company

claims.claim: Defendants operated a fraudulent RoFx.net investment scheme falsely marketed as an AI-powered forex trading platform, defrauding investors.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and state fraud and misrepresentation laws (securities/consumer fraud theories).
claims.outcome: Claims against ePayments Systems Ltd. dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction; claims against other defendants not resolved in this summary.

claims.claim: ePayments Systems Ltd. participated as a co-conspirator in the RoFx.net fraud by processing or facilitating investor payments.
claims.legal_basis: Civil conspiracy and aiding-and-abetting liability under applicable state/federal law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed as to ePayments Systems Ltd. because plaintiffs failed to show purposeful Florida-directed conduct or a Florida-based conspiratorial nexus.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over ePayments Systems Ltd., a UK-based entity, because it did not purposefully direct activities at Florida and had no sufficient nexus to the alleged conspiracy there.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction; Florida long-arm statute requirements.

case_id: 2025-07-25_USCOURTS-ilsd-3_22-cv-00046_Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Use of AI-enabled Lytx DriveCam to analyze drivers’ behavior and biometrics without consent is central to alleged BIPA violations and settlement.

parties.plaintiff_description: Class of drivers using Lytx DriveCam-equipped vehicles
parties.defendant_description: Trucking company and DriveCam AI technology provider

claims.claim: Defendants collected and stored drivers’ biometric identifiers and information via Lytx DriveCam systems without obtaining informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b) – collection and storage of biometric data without written notice and release.
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; court granted final approval and dismissed claims with prejudice in exchange for monetary relief from $4.25 million settlement fund.

claims.claim: Defendants failed to provide a publicly available written policy establishing a retention schedule and guidelines for permanent destruction of biometric identifiers and information collected through DriveCam.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(a) – lack of retention and destruction policy for biometric data.
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; no adjudication on the merits, but settlement approved as fair, reasonable, and adequate with class compensation and case dismissed with prejudice.

claims.claim: Defendants disclosed or otherwise made available drivers’ biometric identifiers and information obtained through DriveCam to third parties without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(d) – unlawful disclosure or dissemination of biometric data without consent.
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; claims released and action dismissed with prejudice upon payment and implementation of settlement terms.

claims.claim: Defendants profited from, or otherwise derived value from, drivers’ biometric identifiers and information collected through the AI-enabled DriveCam system without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(c) – prohibition on selling, leasing, trading, or otherwise profiting from biometric data.
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; no liability finding, but claims released in exchange for settlement fund and related relief.

defenses.defense: Defendants deny any violation of BIPA or other laws and contend their conduct complied with applicable legal requirements.
defenses.legal_basis: General denial of liability under Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act and related statutory and common-law principles.

defenses.defense: Defendants assert that, even if BIPA applied, class certification and recovery would be uncertain due to litigation risks, including issues of consent, extraterritoriality, and damages.
defenses.legal_basis: Procedural and substantive defenses under BIPA and class action standards (Fed. R. Civ. P. 23).

case_name: Risher v. Adecco Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI chatbot Mya sending automated recruiting text messages.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual job seeker and putative class representative
parties.defendant_description: Corporate defendants operating AI-based recruiting text platform

claims.claim: Defendants violated the TCPA by sending unsolicited text messages using an automatic telephone dialing system (autodialer).
claims.legal_basis: Telephone Consumer Protection Act, 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(A) restrictions on calls made using an automatic telephone dialing system.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held the system did not qualify as an autodialer under the Supreme Court’s narrowed definition.

claims.claim: Defendants violated the TCPA by sending unsolicited text messages that used an artificial or prerecorded voice via the AI chatbot Mya.
claims.legal_basis: Telephone Consumer Protection Act, 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(A) prohibition on calls made using an artificial or prerecorded voice without consent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held text messages are not “voice” calls within the meaning of the statute, so the provision did not apply.

defenses.defense: The texting platform, including AI chatbot Mya, is not an automatic telephone dialing system under the TCPA as interpreted by the Supreme Court.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory definition of “automatic telephone dialing system” in 47 U.S.C. § 227(a)(1) and Supreme Court precedent limiting autodialers to systems using a random or sequential number generator.

defenses.defense: Text messages sent by Mya do not use an artificial or prerecorded voice and therefore fall outside the TCPA’s “artificial or prerecorded voice” prohibition.
defenses.legal_basis: Plain-language interpretation of 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(A) and case law distinguishing text messages from voice calls.

case_id: 2022-03-18_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Clearview’s AI facial recognition system created biometric database used by Macy’s.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of individuals alleging biometric privacy violations
parties.defendant_description: Retail corporation accused of using Clearview AI database

claims.claim: Macy’s collected and used plaintiffs’ biometric identifiers and information (facial geometry) via Clearview AI without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b) – collection and use without written notice and release.
claims.outcome: Court held plaintiffs adequately alleged concrete harm under BIPA; Macy’s interlocutory appeal on this issue was denied under 28 U.S.C. § 1292(b).

claims.claim: Macy’s profited from or otherwise benefited from plaintiffs’ biometric data obtained through Clearview AI’s facial recognition database.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(c) – prohibition on selling, leasing, trading, or otherwise profiting from biometric data.
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiffs plausibly alleged that Macy’s use of the database was for profit and within BIPA § 15(c); Macy’s request for interlocutory appeal on this issue was denied under 28 U.S.C. § 1292(b).

claims.claim: Macy’s failed to obtain informed consent and provide required disclosures before using Clearview AI to identify individuals in surveillance footage.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), generally, including 740 ILCS 14/15(a)–(b) (notice, policy, and consent requirements).
claims.outcome: Court concluded the complaint sufficiently alleged violations and concrete privacy harms; no substantial ground for difference of opinion justified interlocutory appeal, so Macy’s motion to certify appeal was denied.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs did not suffer concrete injury and therefore lacked Article III standing for their BIPA claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III standing requirements under the U.S. Constitution; reliance on standing jurisprudence limiting statutory-violation claims without concrete harm.

defenses.defense: The district court’s interpretation of BIPA, including what constitutes profiting from biometric data and sufficient harm, was contestable and warranted interlocutory review.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1292(b) – certification for interlocutory appeal based on controlling question of law and substantial ground for difference of opinion.

case_name: Gutierrez v. Wemagine.AI LLP
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI-powered photo-editing app allegedly misusing biometric data.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual Illinois users bringing BIPA class action
parties.defendant_description: Company operating Voila AI Artist app

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting, storing, and using facial biometric identifiers via the Voila AI Artist app without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach merits of BIPA claim.

claims.claim: Unlawful disclosure and dissemination of users’ biometric identifiers and information to third parties through operation of the Voila AI Artist app.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act provisions restricting disclosure and dissemination of biometric data.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; no ruling on substantive liability.

claims.claim: Failure to develop, publicly disclose, and comply with a written retention schedule and guidelines for permanent destruction of biometric identifiers and information collected through the app.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act requirements for retention schedules and destruction policies.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not address underlying BIPA compliance.

claims.claim: Class action claims on behalf of Illinois users of the Voila AI Artist app whose biometric data was allegedly collected and processed without BIPA-compliant procedures.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 (class action mechanism).
claims.outcome: Entire putative class action dismissed without prejudice due to lack of personal jurisdiction over Wemagine.AI LLP.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction because Wemagine.AI did not purposefully direct its activities at Illinois or specifically target the Illinois market.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Due Process Clause; specific personal jurisdiction standards (minimum contacts, purposeful availment).

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs’ alleged injuries do not arise out of or relate to any Illinois-specific conduct by Wemagine.AI; app availability nationwide is insufficient.
defenses.legal_basis: Specific jurisdiction “arise out of or relate to” requirement under federal due process jurisprudence.

case_name: Trio v. Turing Video, Inc.
ai_relevance: AI-integrated Turing Shield kiosk allegedly captured and processed facial biometrics.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual employee, proposed class representative
parties.defendant_description: Corporation providing AI-based biometric screening kiosks

claims.claim: Unlawful collection of biometric identifiers and information via Turing Shield without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Court denied defendant’s motion to dismiss; claim may proceed.

claims.claim: Unlawful storage and retention of biometric identifiers and information without a publicly available retention schedule or destruction policy.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(a)
claims.outcome: Court denied defendant’s motion to dismiss; claim may proceed.

claims.claim: Unlawful disclosure or dissemination of biometric identifiers and information to third parties without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(d)
claims.outcome: Court denied defendant’s motion to dismiss; claim may proceed.

claims.claim: Failure to protect biometric identifiers and information with reasonable care and industry-standard safeguards.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(e)
claims.outcome: Court denied defendant’s motion to dismiss; claim may proceed.

claims.claim: Class action claims on behalf of similarly situated individuals subjected to Turing Shield biometric collection without BIPA-compliant notice and consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 (procedural basis for class treatment)
claims.outcome: At motion-to-dismiss stage, court allowed BIPA claims to proceed; class certification not yet decided.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over Turing Video in Illinois.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on specific personal jurisdiction under the Fourteenth Amendment.

defenses.defense: BIPA claims are preempted by Section 301 of the Labor Management Relations Act because they require interpretation of a collective bargaining agreement.
defenses.legal_basis: Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA) § 301 preemption doctrine.

defenses.defense: BIPA claims are barred or preempted by the Public Readiness and Emergency Preparedness Act due to use of Turing Shield for COVID-19 screening.
defenses.legal_basis: Public Readiness and Emergency Preparedness (PREP) Act, 42 U.S.C. § 247d-6d.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim because Turing Shield’s operations do not involve “biometric identifiers” or “biometric information” as defined by BIPA.
defenses.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) statutory definitions and pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).

case_name: Silva v. U.S. Army et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged AI-driven wireless torture and spoofing operations by defendants.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual pro se plaintiff alleging government and corporate conspiracy
parties.defendant_description: Federal agencies and pharmaceutical companies as institutional defendants

claims.claim: Defendants conspired to provide or distribute fake or ineffective drugs to plaintiff.
claims.legal_basis: Unclear tort and product liability theories; conclusory constitutional and statutory references; no specific statute adequately pled.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and failure to state a plausible claim; allegations deemed vague, conclusory, and unfounded.

claims.claim: Defendants subjected plaintiff to wireless torture using advanced, AI-driven technology and spoofing operations.
claims.legal_basis: Unspecified constitutional violations and general federal-question jurisdiction; no concrete statutory or constitutional cause of action adequately alleged.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and failure to state a claim; allegations found implausible and unsupported by factual detail.

claims.claim: Overall conspiracy among federal agencies and pharmaceutical companies to harm plaintiff through fake drugs and technological harassment.
claims.legal_basis: General conspiracy theories without specific legal foundation; attempted invocation of federal-question jurisdiction.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held conspiracy allegations were speculative, conclusory, and insufficient to establish jurisdiction or a viable cause of action.

defenses.defense: Court lacks subject matter jurisdiction over plaintiff’s speculative and insubstantial federal claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal subject matter jurisdiction standards; claims deemed frivolous and insubstantial under Rule 12(b)(1).

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted because allegations are vague, conclusory, and implausible.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); Twombly/Iqbal plausibility standard.

case_name: Phi Theta Kappa Honor Society v. HonorSociety.org
ai_relevance: Dispute involves use of generative AI to create misleading online content.

parties.plaintiff_description: Honor society for community college students
parties.defendant_description: Competing online-based honor society organization

claims.claim: HonorSociety.org disseminated false and misleading statements about Phi Theta Kappa online, including AI-generated content, to divert or confuse prospective members and harm PTK’s reputation and business.
claims.legal_basis: False advertising and unfair competition under trademark/consumer protection principles; related injunctive relief under federal law (likely Lanham Act) and state law.
claims.outcome: District court granted a broad preliminary injunction restricting HonorSociety.org’s speech and requiring corrective statements; on appeal, the Fifth Circuit vacated the injunction as overbroad and unconstitutional prior restraint/compelled speech and remanded for further proceedings.

claims.claim: HonorSociety.org’s misleading online content, including content produced with generative AI, constituted deceptive trade practices harming PTK and consumers.
claims.legal_basis: State deceptive trade practices and unfair competition statutes; equitable injunctive relief.
claims.outcome: Preliminary injunctive relief initially granted by district court; Fifth Circuit vacated the injunction on First Amendment grounds and remanded, leaving underlying liability claims unresolved.

defenses.defense: The injunction imposed by the district court was an overbroad prior restraint on speech and impermissibly compelled speech in violation of the First Amendment.
defenses.legal_basis: First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution; prior restraint and compelled speech doctrines; appellate review of equitable injunctions.

defenses.defense: Any disputed statements about Phi Theta Kappa are protected speech or at least cannot be categorically enjoined in the sweeping manner ordered by the district court.
defenses.legal_basis: First Amendment protections for speech, including commercial and comparative speech; limits on injunctive relief against speech.

case_id: 2020-12-07_USCOURTS-cand-5_20-mc-80141_In re Rule 45 Subpoenas Issued to Google LLC and LinkedIn Corporation Dated July 23_ 2020.pdf
case_name: In re Rule 45 Subpoenas Issued to Google LLC and LinkedIn Corporation Dated July 23, 2020
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on online criticism of Spider Labs’ claimed AI-based ad fraud detection technology.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation alleging defamation over online statements
parties.defendant_description: Anonymous individual online speaker

claims.claim: Request to enforce Rule 45 subpoenas to Google and LinkedIn to unmask John Doe’s identity for a contemplated defamation lawsuit.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45; underlying state defamation law; argument that Doe’s statements were false factual assertions harming Spider Labs’ reputation and business.
claims.outcome: Denied implicitly when the court granted John Doe’s motion to quash; subpoenas not enforced and Doe’s identity remained protected.

claims.claim: Alleged defamation by John Doe’s anonymous online statements questioning Spider Labs’ claims about using AI to detect ad fraud and implying its technology was ineffective or misleading.
claims.legal_basis: State defamation law (libel); theory that Doe published false statements of fact causing reputational and economic harm.
claims.outcome: Court held Spider Labs failed to present competent evidence establishing a prima facie case of defamation; no unmasking and no further action on the defamation claim at this stage.

defenses.defense: Motion to quash subpoenas to Google and LinkedIn seeking Doe’s identity.
defenses.legal_basis: First Amendment right to anonymous speech; requirement that a subpoena seeking to unmask an anonymous speaker be supported by a prima facie case of defamation and competent evidence; Rule 45 protections against undue burden and improper purpose.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court granted the motion to quash; subpoenas to Google and LinkedIn were invalidated and Doe’s anonymity preserved.

defenses.defense: Doe’s online statements were protected opinion and/or not shown to be false or defamatory.
defenses.legal_basis: First Amendment protections for opinion and criticism; defamation elements requiring falsity, defamatory meaning, and evidence of harm; burden on Spider Labs to show a prima facie case before unmasking.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted in substance: court found Spider Labs had not provided sufficient competent evidence of defamation, so Doe’s speech remained protected and identity was not disclosed.

case_id: 2020-12-21_USCOURTS-mied-2_17-cv-10657_Cahoo et al v. SAS Analytics Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Cahoo et al. v. SAS Analytics Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on automated algorithmic fraud-detection system (MiDAS) used for unemployment claims.

parties.plaintiff_description: Unemployment claimants challenging automated fraud determinations
parties.defendant_description: Private vendors helping develop MiDAS fraud-detection system

claims.claim: Procedural due process violations arising from automated fraud determinations made by MiDAS without adequate notice or opportunity to be heard.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution, Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause (procedural due process).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction denied; procedural due process claim allowed to proceed against defendants.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack Article III standing because their injuries are not fairly traceable to defendants’ conduct related to MiDAS.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III standing requirements under the U.S. Constitution (injury-in-fact, traceability, redressability).

defenses.defense: Court lacks subject matter jurisdiction due to absence of standing.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1) and constitutional limits on federal jurisdiction.

case_name: Jones v. Douglas County Jail
ai_relevance: Petitioner alleged AI intervention in his criminal cases; court found claims meritless and unsupported.

parties.plaintiff_description: Pretrial detainee and habeas petitioner
parties.defendant_description: County detention facility and custodial authority

claims.claim: His pretrial detention and criminal proceedings were unlawfully delayed due to delays in competency evaluations and trial scheduling.
claims.legal_basis: Federal habeas corpus under 28 U.S.C. § 2241; alleged violations of Sixth Amendment speedy trial rights and Fourteenth Amendment due process.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for failure to exhaust available state court remedies and for not adequately presenting a cognizable federal constitutional claim.

claims.claim: State court and jail actions regarding his competency evaluation and related procedures violated his rights under state law.
claims.legal_basis: Kansas state law governing competency evaluations and criminal procedure (state statutory and procedural rights).
claims.outcome: Dismissed because federal habeas relief is not available for alleged violations of state law alone; no independent federal constitutional issue stated.

claims.claim: Conditions and experiences of confinement at Douglas County Jail violated his constitutional rights (including Eighth and/or Fourteenth Amendment protections).
claims.legal_basis: Eighth Amendment prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment and Fourteenth Amendment due process protections for pretrial detainees, asserted via § 2241 habeas corpus.
claims.outcome: Dismissed because such conditions-of-confinement claims are not properly brought via habeas corpus and were not exhausted in state court; no specific, substantiated federal constitutional violation found.

claims.claim: Artificial intelligence (AI) intervention or influence improperly affected his criminal cases and legal proceedings, contributing to rights violations.
claims.legal_basis: Implied due process and fair trial protections under the Fourteenth and Sixth Amendments, asserted through § 2241 habeas corpus.
claims.outcome: Rejected as meritless; the court found no factual support or legal basis for the AI-intervention allegations and denied relief on these grounds.

defenses.defense: Petitioner failed to exhaust available state court remedies before seeking federal habeas relief.
defenses.legal_basis: Exhaustion requirement for state pretrial detainees seeking federal habeas under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and related precedent.

defenses.defense: Petitioner’s allegations concern only state-law issues and do not present a cognizable federal constitutional claim.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal habeas corpus under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and § 2254 provides relief only for violations of the Constitution, laws, or treaties of the United States; state-law errors are not grounds for federal habeas relief.

defenses.defense: Allegations of AI intervention are conclusory and unsupported, failing to state any plausible constitutional violation.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards for habeas petitions and constitutional claims; requirement of specific factual allegations to show a deprivation of federal rights.

case_name: Clark v. Microsoft Corporation
ai_relevance: AI-driven video coaching software using Azure Cognitive Services to analyze facial expressions and alleged biometric data processing is central to the dispute.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual employee and proposed class representative
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation providing cloud and AI services

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA §15(a) for failing to develop, publicly disclose, and comply with a written policy on retention and destruction of biometric identifiers and information related to facial analysis data processed through Brainshark using Microsoft Azure and Azure Cognitive Services.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; claim plausibly alleged and allowed to proceed against Microsoft on a theory of possession and control of biometric data.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA §15(b) for collecting, capturing, or otherwise obtaining biometric identifiers or information (facial geometry data) without providing required written notice and obtaining written informed consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court found insufficient allegations that Microsoft took active steps to obtain plaintiff’s biometric data, but granted leave to amend.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA §15(c) for profiting from, or otherwise benefiting from, the sale or use of biometric identifiers or information derived from plaintiff’s facial data.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(c)
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction; court held plaintiff failed to allege a concrete personal harm from Microsoft’s alleged profiting, and dismissal was without prejudice to replead if jurisdictional defects can be cured.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA §15(d) for disclosing, redisclosing, or otherwise disseminating biometric identifiers or information to third parties without consent or statutory authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court found insufficient factual allegations that Microsoft actively disseminated plaintiff’s biometric data, but allowed leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Microsoft did not actively collect or obtain plaintiff’s biometric identifiers or information, but merely provided cloud and AI infrastructure used by Brainshark, so it is not liable under BIPA §§15(b) and 15(d).
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of BIPA §§15(b) and 15(d) requiring active collection or dissemination by the defendant.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks Article III standing for the BIPA §15(c) claim because he did not allege a concrete, particularized injury from Microsoft’s alleged profiting from biometric data.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III standing requirements; case-or-controversy and concrete injury doctrine.

defenses.defense: Any alleged possession or control of biometric data by Microsoft is insufficiently pled or too attenuated to impose BIPA obligations on Microsoft as a non-end-user service provider.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of BIPA §15(a) and general pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).

case_id: 2024-04-18_USCOURTS-ca10-22-01402_Underwood_ et al v. Bank of America Corporation.pdf
case_name: Underwood et al. v. Bank of America Corporation
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI virtual assistant trademarks: plaintiffs’ E.R.I.C.A. vs. BofA’s ERICA.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual entrepreneur and associated media/tech corporation
parties.defendant_description: Large national banking and financial services corporation

claims.claim: Federal trademark infringement based on alleged prior unregistered service mark “E.R.I.C.A.” for a virtual assistant.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) – infringement of unregistered mark through likelihood of confusion.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment for Bank of America; court held plaintiffs lacked a protectable interest because they failed to show actual use in commerce that clearly distinguished and identified their services.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and false designation of origin arising from Bank of America’s use of “ERICA” for its virtual financial assistant.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) – unfair competition/false designation of origin.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment for Bank of America; without a protectable interest in “E.R.I.C.A.”, plaintiffs’ unfair competition theory failed.

claims.claim: Related state-law trademark and unfair competition claims premised on ownership of the “E.R.I.C.A.” mark.
claims.legal_basis: State trademark and unfair competition statutes and common law (following federal standards).
claims.outcome: Summary judgment for Bank of America; state claims failed because plaintiffs did not establish protectable rights in the mark through actual use in commerce.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs have no protectable rights in the unregistered “E.R.I.C.A.” mark because they never used it in commerce in a way that clearly distinguished and identified their services.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act requirement of actual use in commerce to create rights in an unregistered mark; burden on plaintiff to show distinct, source-identifying use.

defenses.defense: Without a protectable mark, there can be no likelihood of confusion or liability for trademark infringement or unfair competition.
defenses.legal_basis: Trademark infringement and unfair competition under the Lanham Act and parallel state law require a valid, protectable mark as a threshold element.

case_name: Gjovik v. Apple Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff used generative AI to draft filings; court warned about inaccuracies and counsel’s duty to verify AI-generated content.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual former employee of Apple
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation and employer

claims.claim: Motion to strike Apple’s affirmative defenses as insufficient, conclusory, or improper under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(f) (motion to strike insufficient defenses) and pleading standards under Rules 8 and 9.
claims.outcome: Granted in part and denied in part; some affirmative defenses were stricken with leave to amend, others were allowed to stand as pled.

claims.claim: Motion for a more definite statement regarding Apple’s responses and affirmative defenses, arguing they were too vague or ambiguous to allow a proper response.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(e) (motion for more definite statement).
claims.outcome: Denied in full; the court held Rule 12(e) was procedurally inapplicable to the challenged filings and that Apple’s responses were sufficiently clear under the rules.

defenses.defense: Apple’s affirmative defenses were adequately pled and met the applicable notice-pleading standard, so they should not be stricken.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 8(b) and 8(c) governing defenses and notice pleading; case law allowing concise, general affirmative defenses at early stages.

defenses.defense: A motion for a more definite statement is not the proper vehicle to challenge the clarity of answers or affirmative defenses, and Apple’s existing responses are sufficiently definite.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(e) limiting such motions to pleadings that are so vague or ambiguous a party cannot reasonably prepare a response; related precedent disfavoring Rule 12(e) motions against answers.

case_name: Dopp v. Wray et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges implanted chip and AI used to cause psychological and physical harm.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual pro se plaintiff alleging implanted chip harms
parties.defendant_description: Federal officials and related government defendants

claims.claim: Defendants implanted a chip in plaintiff’s body that causes psychological and physical harm.
claims.legal_basis: Implied constitutional and tort claims (e.g., bodily integrity, assault, battery, intentional infliction of emotional distress), though not plausibly pleaded.
claims.outcome: Dismissed as frivolous for lack of any factual or legal basis; case dismissed without prejudice.

claims.claim: Defendants use artificial intelligence and radio frequencies, via the implanted chip, to control or manipulate plaintiff and cause ongoing harm.
claims.legal_basis: Implied constitutional violations (e.g., due process, cruel and unusual punishment) and unspecified federal civil rights claims, though not supported by facts or cognizable legal theory.
claims.outcome: Dismissed as frivolous; court found allegations wholly incredible and legally baseless.

claims.claim: Defendants are responsible for ongoing psychological torment and physical suffering through remote technological surveillance and interference.
claims.legal_basis: Unspecified civil rights and tort theories under federal question jurisdiction, inadequately pleaded and factually unsupported.
claims.outcome: Dismissed as frivolous; no plausible claim stated under any recognizable legal theory.

claims.claim: Plaintiff seeks to proceed in forma pauperis (without prepaying court fees) to pursue these claims.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915 application to proceed without prepayment of fees.
claims.outcome: Denied as moot because the underlying complaint was dismissed as frivolous.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s allegations are fanciful, delusional, and lack any arguable basis in fact or law, rendering the complaint frivolous.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B)(i) – court’s duty to dismiss frivolous in forma pauperis actions.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state any cognizable legal claim against the named defendants, even if the facts were accepted as true.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted under federal pleading standards (Rule 8 and Rule 12(b)(6) principles).

case_name: Stein v. Clarifai, Inc.
ai_relevance: Defendant allegedly used AI facial recognition to extract biometric data from online photos without consent.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual Illinois resident, putative class representative
parties.defendant_description: Technology company providing AI facial recognition services

claims.claim: Violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) for collecting, capturing, and using biometric identifiers and information from plaintiff’s OKCupid photos without informed written consent and without required disclosures or data retention policies.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over Clarifai in Illinois; court did not reach the merits of the BIPA claim.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on Clarifai’s alleged benefit from using plaintiff’s and class members’ biometric data and photographs to develop and improve its facial recognition technology without compensation or authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois common law of unjust enrichment.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over Clarifai in Illinois; court did not reach the merits of the unjust enrichment claim.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over Clarifai in Illinois because Clarifai’s contacts with the state are insufficient to establish specific or general jurisdiction.
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment; federal personal jurisdiction standards (minimum contacts and fair play and substantial justice).

defenses.defense: Clarifai’s limited sales and business activities in Illinois, including sales of its demographic model to a small number of Illinois customers, are unrelated to plaintiff’s alleged injuries and therefore cannot support specific jurisdiction.
defenses.legal_basis: Specific personal jurisdiction doctrine requiring that the claim arise out of or relate to defendant’s forum contacts.

defenses.defense: Clarifai is not “at home” in Illinois, so the court cannot exercise general jurisdiction over it.
defenses.legal_basis: General personal jurisdiction doctrine under Daimler AG v. Bauman and related precedent.

case_name: Goins v. Father Flanagan's Boys' Home
ai_relevance: Defendant alleged plaintiff used generative AI, causing inaccurate legal citations.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual employee alleging discrimination and retaliation
parties.defendant_description: Organizational employer operating boys' home facility

claims.claim: Sex discrimination in employment, including termination based on sex.
claims.legal_basis: Federal employment discrimination law (likely Title VII of the Civil Rights Act).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a claim; court found allegations factually unsupported and lacking evidence of discriminatory intent.

claims.claim: Retaliation for filing discrimination charges against employer.
claims.legal_basis: Federal anti-retaliation provisions under employment discrimination law (likely Title VII).
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held claims were procedurally barred as untimely and lacked factual basis showing causal connection or retaliatory motive.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim because allegations do not meet the legal standard for employment discrimination or retaliation.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and substantive standards under federal employment discrimination law.

defenses.defense: Claims are time-barred due to untimely filing of charges or lawsuit.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory filing deadlines and exhaustion requirements under federal employment discrimination statutes (e.g., EEOC charge and limitations periods).

defenses.defense: No evidence of discriminatory or retaliatory intent by employer.
defenses.legal_basis: Burden-shifting and evidentiary standards for discrimination and retaliation claims under federal employment law.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s briefing relied on inaccurate citations, suspected to be generated by AI, undermining credibility and legal sufficiency of arguments.
defenses.legal_basis: Court’s inherent authority to assess reliability of submissions and requirement for accurate citation to legal authority.

case_id: 2025-03-26_USCOURTS-deb-1_23-ap-50370_Ryniker et al v. Washington et al.pdf
case_name: Ryniker et al. v. Washington et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute arises from failed funding of AI solutions company Augustus Intelligence, Inc.

parties.plaintiff_description: Litigation trustee for Augustus and certain investors
parties.defendant_description: Individual alleged investor and contract counterparty

claims.claim: Breach of contract based on Washington’s failure to fund a $50 million investment under the Seed Agreement with Augustus Intelligence, Inc.
claims.legal_basis: State-law breach of contract claim under the Seed Agreement used to solicit and secure investment funds
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court held the Seed Agreement was unenforceable because it was part of a fraudulent scheme to defraud investors, so no enforceable contractual obligation existed.

claims.claim: Assigned Investor Claims brought by the Litigation Trustee on behalf of certain investors against Washington related to the same $50 million investment arrangement and associated misconduct.
claims.legal_basis: State-law claims assigned by third-party investors to the Litigation Trustee, asserted as part of the post-confirmation bankruptcy litigation trust
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction; court found they were third-party, non-estate claims not sufficiently related to the bankruptcy case post-confirmation, so the bankruptcy court lacked jurisdiction to adjudicate them.

defenses.defense: The Seed Agreement is unenforceable because it was part of a fraudulent scheme to induce and defraud investors, and courts will not enforce an illegal or fraudulent contract.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law doctrine that contracts founded on fraud or illegality are void or unenforceable as against public policy.

defenses.defense: The bankruptcy court lacks subject matter jurisdiction over the Assigned Investor Claims because they are third-party claims that do not affect the bankruptcy estate post-confirmation.
defenses.legal_basis: Limits on bankruptcy court jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1334 and 157 and post-confirmation “related to” jurisdiction standards.

case_id: 2020-10-23_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_20-cv-03843_Thornley et al v. Clearview AI_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Thornley et al. v. Clearview AI, Inc.
ai_relevance: Defendant used AI-driven facial recognition to scrape and monetize biometric data.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of Illinois biometric privacy plaintiffs
parties.defendant_description: Company offering AI facial recognition technology services

claims.claim: Clearview AI unlawfully profited from plaintiffs’ biometric identifiers and information without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), including provisions restricting sale, lease, trade, or profit from biometric identifiers/information without informed written consent.
claims.outcome: No merits ruling; federal court found no Article III standing and granted plaintiffs’ motion to remand the case to Illinois state court for further proceedings.

claims.claim: Clearview AI failed to obtain informed written consent before collecting and using plaintiffs’ biometric data via facial recognition scraping of online images.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) informed consent and notice requirements.
claims.outcome: No merits ruling; claim remanded to Illinois state court due to lack of federal subject matter jurisdiction based on absence of concrete injury-in-fact.

claims.claim: Clearview AI’s conduct entitled plaintiffs to statutory damages and attorney’s fees under BIPA for unlawful sale or profit from biometric data.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) statutory damages and fee-shifting provisions.
claims.outcome: Federal court did not reach entitlement to damages or fees; case remanded to state court after finding no Article III injury-in-fact.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lacked Article III standing because they alleged only statutory violations and damages, not a concrete injury-in-fact.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III standing requirements; federal case-or-controversy doctrine as interpreted in Supreme Court and Seventh Circuit precedent.

defenses.defense: Federal court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over purely statutory BIPA claims seeking damages without concrete harm.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1331 and Article III jurisdictional limits requiring concrete injury for federal jurisdiction.

case_name: Hodge v. United States
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged sexual assault committed by artificial intelligence system.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual state pretrial detainee bringing FTCA claims
parties.defendant_description: Federal government sued under Federal Tort Claims Act

claims.claim: Tort claim under the Federal Tort Claims Act based on alleged sexual assault by artificial intelligence while plaintiff was a state pretrial detainee.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA), 28 U.S.C. §§ 1346(b), 2671–2680 (alleged negligence or wrongful act by federal employee).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and failure to state a claim; court held the allegations did not fall within FTCA’s waiver of sovereign immunity and did not identify any negligent act by a federal employee. Dismissal affirmed on appeal as frivolous.

claims.claim: Tort/constitutional-type claim that plaintiff was denied access to legal materials while detained.
claims.legal_basis: Asserted under FTCA and broadly as violation of rights, but without specific statutory or constitutional basis pleaded; treated as part of FTCA complaint.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of jurisdiction and failure to state a claim because no specific negligent act by a federal employee or viable legal theory was alleged. Dismissal affirmed on appeal as frivolous.

claims.claim: Request to proceed in forma pauperis on appeal.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915 (in forma pauperis status for indigent litigants).
claims.outcome: Denied by the Tenth Circuit because the appeal was deemed frivolous and not taken in good faith.

defenses.defense: Sovereign immunity bars the claims because they do not fall within the FTCA’s limited waiver of immunity.
defenses.legal_basis: Sovereign immunity and FTCA jurisdictional limits, 28 U.S.C. §§ 1346(b), 2671–2680.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim due to lack of specific factual allegations tying any injury to a negligent or wrongful act of a federal employee acting within the scope of employment.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and FTCA pleading requirements.

defenses.defense: Claims are frivolous and lack an arguable basis in law or fact, so the appeal should be dismissed and in forma pauperis status denied.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B) (screening and dismissal of frivolous actions and appeals).

case_id: 2024-01-17_USCOURTS-ohsd-3_23-cv-00028_McComb v. Best Buy Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: McComb v. Best Buy Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Court expressly barred use of AI tools to draft any filings.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual pro se plaintiff alleging discrimination
parties.defendant_description: Corporate employer and related business entities

claims.claim: Racial discrimination in employment by Best Buy against McComb.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state anti-discrimination laws (e.g., Title VII).
claims.outcome: No final merits ruling; court required a second amended complaint that complies with Rule 8(a).

claims.claim: Disability discrimination in employment by Best Buy against McComb.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state disability laws (e.g., ADA).
claims.outcome: No final merits ruling; court required a second amended complaint that complies with Rule 8(a).

claims.claim: Procedural sufficiency of the amended complaint under Rule 8(a) (short and plain statement requirement).
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8(a).
claims.outcome: Court found the amended complaint noncompliant (too long and confusing) and granted leave to file a second amended complaint by a set deadline.

defenses.defense: Motion to dismiss the amended complaint for failure to state a claim and/or failure to comply with pleading standards.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and Rule 8(a).

defenses.defense: Challenge to the sufficiency and clarity of plaintiff’s factual allegations.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8(a) and related case law on pleading standards.

case_name: In re Pinterest Derivative Litigation
ai_relevance: Settlement required Pinterest to use AI to promote diverse, inclusive content representation on its platform.

parties.plaintiff_description: Shareholders bringing derivative claims on Pinterest’s behalf
parties.defendant_description: Public technology company operating image-sharing platform

claims.claim: Derivative claims alleging Pinterest’s directors and officers allowed or engaged in systemic race and sex discrimination in employment and platform practices, harming the company.
claims.legal_basis: State corporate law fiduciary duty principles (duty of loyalty, good faith, oversight) underlying shareholder derivative actions; anti-discrimination norms incorporated via board oversight duties.
claims.outcome: Resolved by court-approved derivative settlement requiring governance, diversity, and inclusivity reforms, including AI-based content diversity measures; no adjudication on the merits.

claims.claim: Request for attorney’s fees and expenses for plaintiffs’ counsel for negotiating the settlement and later monitoring Pinterest’s compliance with the settlement’s diversity and inclusivity reforms.
claims.legal_basis: Common-benefit doctrine in derivative litigation and settlement agreement provisions allowing fee applications for monitoring and enforcement work.
claims.outcome: Court granted motion and awarded $2,500,000 in attorney’s fees based on substantial compliance with settlement terms and the corporate benefits achieved.

defenses.defense: Pinterest substantially complied with the settlement’s governance, diversity, and inclusivity obligations, including implementation of agreed reforms.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract and settlement-enforcement principles; substantial-compliance doctrine limiting additional or reduced obligations when core settlement objectives are met.

defenses.defense: The scope and results of Pinterest’s reforms, including diversity improvements and inclusive content initiatives, justified limiting any further obligations beyond the settlement’s terms.
defenses.legal_basis: Settlement agreement interpretation under contract law; equitable principles governing derivative settlements and fee awards.

case_name: Virtual Radiologic Corporation v. Rabern
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Medical teleradiology services corporation and former employer
parties.defendant_description: Individual former employee and executive

claims.claim: Breach of non-compete agreement by going to work for competitor Nines, Inc.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law; enforcement of restrictive covenant under Minnesota law
claims.outcome: Court found vRad unlikely to succeed on the merits and denied preliminary injunction based on this claim.

claims.claim: Breach of non-solicitation agreement by allegedly soliciting vRad employees or customers for Nines, Inc.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law; enforcement of non-solicitation covenant under Minnesota law
claims.outcome: Court found insufficient evidence of breach or resulting harm and denied preliminary injunction on this ground.

claims.claim: Breach of confidentiality agreement and misuse of confidential information
claims.legal_basis: Contract law; duty to maintain confidentiality of employer’s proprietary information
claims.outcome: Court held vRad had not shown likely misuse or imminent harm; no likelihood of success shown for purposes of preliminary injunction.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to vRad’s confidential business information
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law (likely Minnesota Uniform Trade Secrets Act)
claims.outcome: Court found record did not support likely misappropriation or threat of irreparable harm; injunction denied.

claims.claim: Fraudulent inducement / misrepresentation regarding the nature of Nines’ business to obtain modification of restrictive covenants
claims.legal_basis: Common-law fraud and misrepresentation under Minnesota law
claims.outcome: Court concluded vRad had not shown a likelihood of proving fraud or misrepresentation; no basis for preliminary injunction.

defenses.defense: No breach of non-compete or non-solicitation because Nines is not a direct competitor as represented and activities fall outside the covenants’ scope.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation under Minnesota law; restrictive covenants construed narrowly.

defenses.defense: No misappropriation or use of vRad’s confidential information or trade secrets in work for Nines.
defenses.legal_basis: Requirements of trade secret misappropriation statutes and common law; need for proof of use or disclosure.

defenses.defense: vRad cannot show irreparable harm from Rabern’s employment at Nines.
defenses.legal_basis: Preliminary injunction standard under federal law (Dataphase factors) requiring proof of irreparable harm.

defenses.defense: vRad is unlikely to succeed on the merits of its contract and fraud claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard; burden on movant to show likelihood of success.

defenses.defense: Any alleged misrepresentation about Nines’ business was not false or not material, and vRad did not reasonably rely on it.
defenses.legal_basis: Elements of common-law fraud and misrepresentation under Minnesota law.

case_name: Long, M.D., et al. v. Facebook, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs alleged Facebook used scraping and neural-network tools to detect infringement, but court found this did not show actual knowledge of specific infringements.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual author and publishing company
parties.defendant_description: Social media and technology corporation

claims.claim: Contributory copyright infringement based on infringing posts on Facebook page after hacking incident
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, contributory infringement doctrine; 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court held plaintiffs failed to plausibly allege Facebook’s actual knowledge of specific infringing material, and Facebook remained protected by DMCA safe harbor.

claims.claim: Vicarious copyright infringement (implicit in copyright suit against platform)
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, vicarious infringement doctrine; 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Effectively dismissed with prejudice along with contributory claim; plaintiffs did not cure pleading defects and could not proceed against Facebook.

defenses.defense: Lack of actual or specific knowledge of infringing material on the platform
defenses.legal_basis: Contributory copyright infringement requires actual knowledge of specific infringements; failure to plead such knowledge warrants dismissal.

defenses.defense: DMCA safe harbor protection for online service providers
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 512; Facebook qualifies for safe harbor because it lacked actual knowledge of specific infringements and removed material when properly notified.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim in the second amended complaint
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); plaintiffs did not cure prior pleading deficiencies regarding knowledge and specific infringing acts.

case_id: 2025-08-26_USCOURTS-dcd-1_25-cv-01567_CATALDO v. UNITED STATES OF AMERICA et al.pdf
case_name: CATALDO v. UNITED STATES OF AMERICA et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff challenges risks and development of advanced AI systems by government and tech companies.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual pro se litigant raising AI-related fears
parties.defendant_description: Federal government and private AI/technology corporations

claims.claim: General challenge to development and deployment of advanced artificial intelligence systems by the federal government and major technology companies (including OpenAI and Google), based on fears of future harm and societal risks.
claims.legal_basis: No specific statutory or constitutional cause of action identified; complaint consisted of generalized fears and speculative harms without concrete injury or recognized legal theory.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice as frivolous under 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B)(i) for lack of legal basis and fantastical, non-justiciable allegations.

claims.claim: Request for court intervention or regulation to halt, limit, or oversee advanced AI development due to alleged existential or large-scale dangers posed by such technologies.
claims.legal_basis: No articulated legal authority granting the court power to impose broad AI policy or regulatory controls; no standing or justiciable controversy established.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice as frivolous under 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B)(i); court declined to entertain policy-based, non-legal grievances.

claims.claim: Application to proceed in forma pauperis to avoid paying filing fees for the lawsuit.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(a) (request to proceed without prepayment of fees based on alleged indigence).
claims.outcome: Denied because plaintiff failed to provide sufficient financial disclosure and the underlying complaint was deemed frivolous under 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B)(i).

defenses.defense: Complaint is frivolous and based on fantastical, speculative allegations about AI, lacking any cognizable legal claim or concrete injury.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B)(i) (court must dismiss frivolous in forma pauperis actions).

defenses.defense: Plaintiff fails to state a justiciable case or controversy, including lack of standing and absence of a specific cause of action against the government or tech companies regarding AI development.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III case-or-controversy and standing requirements; general failure-to-state-a-claim principles under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(1) and 12(b)(6) (as applied through § 1915 screening).

case_name: Deyerler v. HireVue Inc.
ai_relevance: AI-powered video interview software allegedly captured and analyzed applicants’ biometric data.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of Illinois job applicants under BIPA
parties.defendant_description: Company providing AI video interview and assessment software

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(a) for failing to develop, publicly disclose, and comply with a written policy on retention and destruction of biometric identifiers and information collected from Illinois job applicants via HireVue’s AI interview software.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; § 15(a) claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(b) for collecting, capturing, or otherwise obtaining plaintiffs’ biometric identifiers and/or biometric information (e.g., facial geometry) through AI-driven video interview tools without providing required written notice and obtaining informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(b).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; § 15(b) claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(c) for profiting from, or otherwise receiving a thing of value for, plaintiffs’ biometric identifiers and information collected through the AI interview platform.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(c).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted; § 15(c) claim dismissed for failure to adequately allege direct profit from biometric data itself or individualized harm.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(d) for disclosing, redisclosing, or otherwise disseminating plaintiffs’ biometric identifiers or information obtained via the AI interview system without consent or statutory authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; § 15(d) claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(e) for failing to use reasonable care in storing, transmitting, and protecting biometric identifiers and information collected through the AI-powered interview platform.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(e).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; § 15(e) claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Class action claim seeking statutory damages, injunctive relief, and other remedies for all similarly situated Illinois job applicants whose biometric data was collected and processed by HireVue’s AI interview software.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.; Illinois class action procedural rules.
claims.outcome: Case allowed to proceed on a class basis at pleading stage; no dismissal of class allegations at this stage.

claims.claim: Assertion that the Illinois federal court has specific personal jurisdiction over HireVue based on its provision and use of AI interview software for an Illinois-based employer and Illinois applicants.
claims.legal_basis: Due Process Clause; Illinois long-arm statute; specific personal jurisdiction doctrine.
claims.outcome: Court held specific personal jurisdiction exists; motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction because HireVue is not based in Illinois and its contacts with Illinois were allegedly insufficient to support specific jurisdiction.
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause; minimum contacts and specific personal jurisdiction standards under federal constitutional law.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim under BIPA § 15(c) because plaintiffs did not plausibly allege that HireVue sold, leased, traded, or otherwise profited from biometric identifiers or information themselves, as opposed to generally selling software services.
defenses.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act § 15(c); Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: General Rule 12(b)(6) challenge that the complaint did not adequately plead elements of certain BIPA violations, including insufficient allegations of individualized harm and statutory violations tied to specific conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); pleading standards under Twombly and Iqbal.

case_id: 2025-10-08_USCOURTS-nmd-1_23-cv-00899_Lipe v. Albuquerque Public Schools et al.pdf
case_name: Lipe v. Albuquerque Public Schools et al.
ai_relevance: Court addressed plaintiff’s counsel’s use of generative AI to draft filings and warned counsel to carefully review AI-generated content for accuracy and legal sufficiency.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual plaintiff suing school district
parties.defendant_description: Public school district and related defendants

claims.claim: Request by Albuquerque Public Schools for a 10-day extension to provide supplemental discovery responses.
claims.legal_basis: Federal civil procedure standard for extensions of time upon showing of good cause (e.g., Fed. R. Civ. P. 6(b)) and discovery obligations under the Federal Rules.
claims.outcome: Granted. The court found good cause based on unforeseen circumstances affecting defense counsel’s law clerk and no evidence of bad faith or undue prejudice to plaintiff.
