claims.claim: Plaintiff’s opposition to the extension, asserting delay and potential prejudice from late supplemental discovery responses.
claims.legal_basis: General principles of timely discovery, avoidance of undue delay, and potential prejudice to the requesting party under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.
claims.outcome: Denied/overruled. The court rejected plaintiff’s arguments, concluding that the short extension would not unduly prejudice plaintiff and that the defense had shown good cause.

claims.claim: Implicit challenge to adequacy and professionalism of plaintiff’s counsel’s filings due to apparent reliance on generative AI that produced unwarranted legal contentions.
claims.legal_basis: Attorney professional responsibility and duty of competence, candor to the court, and Rule 11-type obligations to ensure factual and legal support for filings.
claims.outcome: No formal sanctions imposed, but the court issued a cautionary admonition directing plaintiff’s counsel to diligently review any AI-drafted filings to ensure accuracy, proper legal grounding, and compliance with professional and procedural standards.

defenses.defense: Good cause exists for a 10-day extension to supplement discovery responses due to unforeseen circumstances involving defense counsel’s law clerk.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 6(b) and related good-cause standard for modifying deadlines.

defenses.defense: The requested extension will not unduly prejudice plaintiff and is not sought in bad faith or for purposes of delay.
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable considerations under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing case management and discovery, including absence of bad faith and minimal prejudice to the opposing party.

case_id: 2025-09-08_USCOURTS-mnd-0_23-cv-03514_Estate of Gene B. Lokken_ The et al v. UnitedHealth Group_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Estate of Gene B. Lokken, et al. v. UnitedHealth Group, Inc., et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege defendants used nH Predict AI tool instead of human medical directors to make coverage decisions in breach of insurance contracts.

parties.plaintiff_description: Estate and other insureds in putative class action
parties.defendant_description: Health insurer and affiliate using AI coverage tool

claims.claim: Improper denial of medical coverage using nH Predict instead of promised human medical review
claims.legal_basis: Breach of insurance contracts and plan terms; bad-faith claims handling under applicable insurance/ERISA law (class-action context)
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; litigation proceeds with unified discovery after denial of bifurcation.

claims.claim: Class-wide relief for all similarly situated insureds allegedly subjected to AI-based coverage denials
claims.legal_basis: Class-action claims under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 based on uniform contractual and statutory violations
claims.outcome: Class certification not decided; court allows class and merits discovery to proceed together.

claims.claim: Procedural request for full, non-bifurcated discovery on both named plaintiffs’ merits and class issues
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 1 and 26; opposition to defendants’ motion to bifurcate discovery
claims.outcome: Court agreed with plaintiffs and denied defendants’ motion to bifurcate discovery.

defenses.defense: Request to bifurcate discovery so that only named plaintiffs’ merits are litigated first, delaying class-wide discovery and certification issues
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 23 and 26; judicial economy and proportionality arguments for phased discovery

defenses.defense: Argument that early focus on named plaintiffs’ individual coverage disputes could obviate or narrow need for class discovery and certification
defenses.legal_basis: Case-management discretion of the court under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 16 and inherent judicial authority

case_name: Zaletel v. Prisma Labs, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI-powered photo-art app name and branding.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual app developer and trademark owner
parties.defendant_description: Corporation offering AI-based photo art app

claims.claim: Trademark infringement based on reverse confusion between PRIZMIA and PRISMA marks for mobile photo/video applications.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 32 and related federal trademark infringement law (reverse confusion theory).
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiff had not shown likelihood of success on the merits at the preliminary injunction stage; motion for preliminary injunction denied.

claims.claim: Trademark infringement and unfair competition under related federal and/or state law arising from defendant’s use of PRISMA for its app.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) and analogous state unfair competition principles.
claims.outcome: Court held plaintiff failed to show likelihood of confusion or irreparable harm; preliminary injunctive relief denied.

defenses.defense: No likelihood of confusion between PRIZMIA and PRISMA marks, including under reverse confusion theory.
defenses.legal_basis: Trademark infringement standards under the Lanham Act; multi-factor likelihood-of-confusion analysis.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to show irreparable harm from defendant’s continued use of PRISMA mark.
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable requirements for preliminary injunction under federal law.

case_name: Berg v. United Airlines et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff used AI to draft filings that contained fake legal citations, leading court to strike her summary judgment responses.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual passenger and pro se litigant
parties.defendant_description: Commercial airline and additional associated defendants

claims.claim: Substantive civil claims against United Airlines and others (underlying merits not detailed in summary).
claims.legal_basis: Unspecified civil causes of action in original complaint (not described in provided summary).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; case remains pending while plaintiff is given one final opportunity to properly respond to United’s summary judgment motion.

claims.claim: Plaintiff’s attempt to amend her complaint at this late stage of litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15 and related scheduling/order modification standards requiring good cause and compliance with procedural rules.
claims.outcome: Denied; court found non-compliance with procedural rules and lack of good cause, so amendment of the complaint was not permitted.

claims.claim: Plaintiff’s late and procedurally improper responses to United Airlines’ motion for summary judgment, including use of AI-generated content with fake citations.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and local court rules governing filing deadlines, form of briefs, and duty of candor and accuracy in citations.
claims.outcome: United’s motion to strike was granted; plaintiff’s existing responses to the summary judgment motion were stricken as untimely and improper due to AI-generated content with fake legal citations. Court allowed plaintiff one final chance to file a compliant response by a specified date.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s summary judgment responses were untimely and violated procedural rules.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and local rules on filing deadlines and proper motion practice.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s filings improperly relied on AI-generated content containing fake legal citations, rendering them unreliable and noncompliant.
defenses.legal_basis: Court’s inherent authority to manage its docket, enforce rules, and require accurate, good-faith legal citations and representations.

defenses.defense: Amendment of the complaint at this stage would be improper due to lack of good cause and failure to follow required procedures.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15 and standards for modifying scheduling orders and allowing late amendments.

case_name: Ryan v. X Corp.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges X used AI system to target and suspend his accounts without proper notice, forming part of his unfair business practices theory.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual social media user and account holder
parties.defendant_description: Social media platform corporation

claims.claim: Promissory fraud based on alleged promises regarding continued account access or treatment of his accounts
claims.legal_basis: State-law promissory fraud; challenged under and limited by X Corp.’s Terms of Service
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held claim barred by X’s Terms of Service, which expressly allow account suspension and limit liability for such actions.

claims.claim: Promissory estoppel based on alleged promises that his accounts would not be suspended or would be treated in a particular way
claims.legal_basis: State-law promissory estoppel; subject to contractual limitations in X Corp.’s Terms of Service
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found the Terms of Service control the relationship, permit suspension, and preclude liability, defeating any promissory estoppel theory.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment for retaining benefits (such as payments or value from his use of the platform) while suspending his accounts
claims.legal_basis: State-law unjust enrichment; additionally subject to immunity under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act
claims.outcome: Dismissed; independently barred by Section 230 CDA and also precluded by the Terms of Service that authorize suspension and limit liability.

claims.claim: Unfair business practices, including alleged unfair use of an AI system to target and suspend his accounts without proper notice
claims.legal_basis: State-law unfair business practices statute (e.g., consumer protection law), constrained by X Corp.’s Terms of Service and Section 230 principles
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held the Terms of Service authorize account suspension and disclaim liability, so the unfair business practices claim, including AI-related allegations, cannot proceed.

defenses.defense: Contractual right to suspend accounts and limit liability under Terms of Service
defenses.legal_basis: Enforceability of X Corp.’s Terms of Service as binding contract governing user accounts, expressly permitting suspension and excluding liability for such actions.

defenses.defense: Section 230 immunity from liability for unjust enrichment claim
defenses.legal_basis: Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act shields X Corp. from liability arising from its moderation and suspension decisions, independently barring the unjust enrichment claim.

case_id: 2024-03-14_USCOURTS-cand-5_23-cv-05181_Playground AI LLC v. Mighty Computing_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Playground AI LLC v. Mighty Computing, Inc., et al.
ai_relevance: Trademark dispute between AI-focused companies over use of the “Playground AI” brand.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology company offering AI services
parties.defendant_name: Mighty Computing, Inc. and Suhail Doshi
parties.defendant_description: AI-focused corporation and its individual founder/executive

claims.claim: Trademark infringement against Mighty Computing, Inc. and Suhail Doshi related to use of the “Playground AI” mark.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trademark law (e.g., Lanham Act §32/§43(a)).
claims.outcome: Court held plaintiff plausibly alleged personal liability of Doshi; his motion to dismiss the trademark infringement claim was denied and the claim proceeds.

claims.claim: Cybersquatting against Mighty Computing, Inc. and Suhail Doshi for registering/using domain names incorporating the “Playground AI” mark.
claims.legal_basis: Anticybersquatting Consumer Protection Act (ACPA), 15 U.S.C. §1125(d).
claims.outcome: Court held plaintiff plausibly alleged Doshi’s personal involvement; his motion to dismiss the cybersquatting claim was denied and the claim proceeds.

defenses.defense: Suhail Doshi argued he could not be held personally liable for trademark infringement because any alleged conduct was undertaken by Mighty Computing, Inc., not by him individually.
defenses.legal_basis: Corporate officer limited-liability principles; requirement of direct participation or control for personal liability under trademark law.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court rejected this argument at the pleading stage, finding plausible allegations of his direct involvement and control; motion to dismiss denied.

defenses.defense: Suhail Doshi argued he could not be personally liable for cybersquatting because he did not personally register or control the allegedly infringing domains beyond his corporate role.
defenses.legal_basis: Corporate separateness and personal participation doctrine under the ACPA.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court found sufficient allegations that he was the central decision-maker behind the challenged conduct; motion to dismiss denied.
